text: the best hitter in baseball my opinion
was Ted Williams trying to sneak a
fastball by Ted away or like trying to
sneak a sunbeam by a rooster in the
morning Robert William Andrew feller
otherwise known as Bob Feller is
considered one of the greatest baseball
pitchers ever to play the game in 1936
the 17-year old high school senior came
off an Iowa farm and went straight to
the major leagues where he dominated the
sport for two decades he set numerous
pitching records many since broken and
pitched three no-hitters including one
against the Chicago White Sox on opening
day 1940 and yet just as he became the
sport's biggest draw since Babe Ruth
he put his baseball career on hold to
serve four years in the Navy during
World War two there was no way that we
were not gonna win at war because it
people at home as well as the people in
the military had unrelenting resolve
that we were gonna win Bob Feller was
born in Van Meter Iowa in 1918 he grew
up on a farm where his father devoted
himself to his hogs his corn and his
sons evident talent for throwing a
baseball
my father recognized I had a very good
arm and I loved to play the game I loved
to play with him and play catch we build
a ball diamond on the farm in the past
year pinched it off to keep the
livestock off the off the outfield in
the in the field my father would hit fly
ball is human ground balls he catch and
we tried to learn all the fundamentals
by kind of trial and error method in
1928 when bob was 11
two of his idols came to town on a
barnstorming tour Babe Ruth and Lou
Gehrig they were selling balls that day
at the game and they had been signed
previously by Babe and Lou at the hotel
and they charge $5 for the balls and
that date and timing they gave ten cents
a pair for golfers who were chewing up
all the the clover and the alfalfa and
ruining
the fields and so they keep bounty and I
caught 50 of them we got 10 cents a pair
Bobby that's where I got the 5 dollars
to buy the ball so of course everybody
kids about that's your first gopher ball
by 1935 fellers baseball skills were
apparent and the Cleveland Indians
signed the 16 year old to a contract
while on summer break before starting
his senior year of high school the
precocious right-hander made his major
league debut well I spent about 15 my
first starting at the st. Louis Brown
now the Baltimore Orioles and then later
on I got 17 Philadelphia Athletics
and in early September then I went back
to school the season was over and had a
tutor to catch that point what's going
on the next spring I had a tutor in
spring training in New Orleans then I
came back and took two weeks away from
the Indians went back and got my diploma
and graduated and got back and joined
the ball club again and continued my
career two years later I struck out 18
which was a major league record for over
30 years I had a slider fast curve
change I working at it trying to throw
strikes I'm the youngest pitcher ever
win the game in the majors they also the
youngest to lose a game when you were 17
and you became this big national
sensation cover of magazines what was
that like for you to suddenly be famous
was that difficult not at all no no my
father and mother were training me
pretty well and I listened to I had very
good coaches teachers managers a lot of
good friends on the team and it wasn't
all that tough I tried to cooperate with
the news media and didn't all love me
but that's okay if you're gonna if
you're going to do anything successful
not everybody's going to love you and
you can't waste your time worrying about
it Bob Feller is one of the hardest
throwers ever to play the game just how
fast was his legendary fastball it's
hard to know for sure because he pitched
in an era before radar guns
lady this stunt in Chicago in 1940 with
a motorcycle motorcycle was going 86 and
I gained 13 feet on the motorcycle 260 V
six inches of pitching distance which
figured out Mathematica
104 I suppose in my prime I can average
on a good day maybe or 102 103 104 maybe
105 occasionally thank you very much
ladies and gentlemen a day that stands
out in fellers memory is June 13th 1948
yes it was Babe Ruth day at Yankee
Stadium and Bob Feller and the Indians
were in town for the game they had Babe
Ruth day every year and Yankee Stadium
put up all the pennants and all the
money made a big deal babe would show up
and speaking home plate but this year he
had throat cancer and he was dying of
throat cancer and he walked up the three
steps into the dugout level reaching the
bat right grabbed a bat at random and
walked up the steps onto the field level
enough to home plate leaned on this bat
and that bat look at Bob Feller bat
there's been so many lovely things said
about me and I'm glad to me picture was
taken him reading on my bat and he
brought it back and one of my players
had an autographed of course I miss
pitching to babe by one year he retired
1935 from the Boston bees and I pictured
Lou Gehrig for two and a half years nice
person very quiet smoked a little smoked
cigarettes
they've always smoked cigars I got to
know him when I was quite pretty well
because I was on several rubber chicken
dinners and banquets and functions
around New York with both of them when I
was a young fella before World War two
on December 7th 1941 Japan like it's
infamous axis partners struck first and
declared war afterwards probably the
biggest decision I ever made in well
